nodes.label: Phishing Indicators
nodes.description: Signals of phishing such as urgency, mismatched sender domains, suspicious links, and unexpected attachments.

nodes.label: Sender Spoofing
nodes.description: Spoofed From/Reply-To/Return-Path fields used to impersonate trusted senders.

nodes.label: URL Obfuscation
nodes.description: Techniques like typosquatting or punycode to disguise malicious destinations.

nodes.label: Malicious Attachment / Macro
nodes.description: Attachments (e.g., .docm) that request enabling macros or execute malware.

nodes.label: Credential Theft
nodes.description: Credential capture, theft, or misuse that enables unauthorized access.

nodes.label: NTLM / Pass-the-Hash
nodes.description: Reuse of NTLM credentials/hashes for authentication across hosts.

nodes.label: Unusual SMB Activity
nodes.description: Anomalous SMB access patterns that can indicate lateral movement.

nodes.label: Remote Execution
nodes.description: Remote execution via tools/protocols like PsExec, WMI, or scheduled tasks.

nodes.label: Privilege Escalation
nodes.description: Gaining higher privileges (user to admin) via misconfiguration or credential access.

nodes.label: Credential Dumping
nodes.description: Attempting to extract credentials from memory or stores (e.g., LSASS).

nodes.label: Data Staging
nodes.description: Collecting and preparing data for exfiltration (e.g., archives).

nodes.label: Exfiltration Channel
nodes.description: Transferring data out via HTTPS, DNS, SMB, or cloud services.

edges.description: Phishing often includes spoofed sender fields.
Phishing often includes suspicious or obfuscated links.
Spoofed email can trick a user into credential entry.
Stolen credentials/hashes may be reused for NTLM authentication.
Stolen credentials used for SMB can create unusual activity.
SMB access can precede remote execution via admin shares or tools.
Privilege escalation attempts may involve credential dumping.
Staged data is transferred via an exfiltration channel.
